author: By Kris Rhim
title: From Tattoos to Malcolm X T-shirts, N.B.A. Hopefuls Talk Style
description: Three top draft prospects — Paolo Banchero, Chet Holmgren and Jalen Williams — explained their approach to fashion. “I feel like I don’t really miss when I put fits on,” Holmgren said.
content: Paolo Banchero lifted the right sleeve of his black hooded sweatshirt to point out the green tattoo ink on his forearm. His long arms make up most of the 7-foot-1 wingspan that positioned him as one of the top prospects in the N.B.A. draft on Thursday, but they also tell a story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford
title: The Next Battlefield for N.Y. Progressives? The State Assembly.
description: A slate of left-wing candidates have mounted robust campaigns to unseat Democratic incumbents, an effort that party leaders characterize as a display of “arrogance.”
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — In the final days of New York’s legislative session, the state’s progressive left-wing seemed poised to score a surprise victory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: Extreme Weather Hits China With Massive Floods and Scorching Heat
description: Hundreds of thousands of people have been displaced by the historic flooding. Elsewhere, record-high temperatures are rupturing roads and driving energy consumption.
content: HONG KONG — China is grappling with extreme weather emergencies across the country, with the worst flooding in decades submerging houses and cars in the south and record-high heat waves in the northern and central provinces causing roads to buckle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Prevost and Anne Mancuso
title: Homes for Sale in Westchester and Connecticut
description: This week’s available properties are a five-bedroom house in Ossining, N.Y., and a four-bedroom in Westport, Conn.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: After Decades of Searching, 1898 Film of New Orleans Mardi Gras Is Found
description: Believed to be the oldest film of New Orleans, the roughly two-minute movie shows both long-held traditions of the parade and rituals that have been changed or forgotten.
content: Arthur Hardy, the publisher of an annual New Orleans Mardi Gras guide, began searching in the 1980s for a film of the parade that old silent film catalogs said had been produced in the 19th century.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Patrick Radden Keefe Has One Big Rule for His Reading Time
description: “My iPhone must be dead, or secured in a lockbox of some sort,” says the journalist and author, whose latest book is the true-crime collection “Rogues.”
content: I’m an appalling reader, promiscuous and inattentive. I spend hours every day reading, but I magpie around and don’t finish things. As a consequence, books tend to pile up on my night stand in teetering stacks, accumulating passive-aggressively, like an accusation. Fortunately, I consider random Jenga towers of books to be the height of sophisticated décor. My wife feels otherwise; but then, she’s one of those systematic readers who finishes every book she starts, so there’s no accounting for taste. Current contents of the stack: “The Silk Roads,” by Peter Frankopan, “Greetings From Bury Park,” by Sarfraz Manzoor, “Vladimir,” by Julia May Jonas (which I finished! So good), “The Island,” by Adrian McKinty, “Franchise,” by Marcia Chatelain, “Prince of the City,” by Robert Daley, the play “King Charles III,” by Mike Bartlett, a book of plays by Lucy Prebble. I am reading all of these books. I will finish some of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By April Rubin
title: To Catch a Snake: Largest Python Found in Everglades Signals a Threat
description: The Burmese python caught by a team of trackers breaks a record and shows the invasive species surviving in Florida’s ecosystem despite efforts to remove those snakes.
content: A team searching under dense vegetation in the pine flatwoods of the Everglades late last year came upon a slithering sight, the likes of which no one had found before in those parts: 215 pounds of snake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: Shared Suffering
description: Ukrainians are trying to confront the war’s psychological wounds even as the battles wear on.
content: Kate Pokrovskaya, a 39-year-old psychotherapist, was asleep at her home in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Feb. 24 when she and her husband were awakened by the sound of explosions. Russia had launched its invasion. “At that moment, our life stopped,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yana Dlugy
title: The E.U. Opens the Door
description: Ukraine gets coveted candidate status to the bloc.
content: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed and Melissa Eddy
title: Russia Crimps Gas Flows Just as Europe Races to Stock Up for Winter
description: The routine summer practice of filling Europe’s natural gas tanks has become a battle after Russia cut deliveries by more than half.
content: Germany’s largest storage chamber for natural gas stretches underneath a swath of farmland the size of nine soccer fields in the western part of the country. The bucolic area has become a kind of battlefield in Europe’s effort to defend itself against a looming gas crisis driven by Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maham Javaid and Dan Bilefsky
title: Amid backlash, Eurovision’s organizers defend why Ukraine cannot host next year’s song contest.
description: Eurovision officials cited the need to guarantee the security of all those involved in the contest, robbing Ukraine, this year’s winner, of the chance to be an international showcase.
content: It was a rare moment of euphoria amid war: In May a Ukrainian hip-hop band won the Eurovision Song Contest, the cultural phenomenon that helped launch Abba and Celine Dion and was watched this year by about 160 million people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Opera’s Lack of Diversity Extends to Offstage, a Study Shows
description: Opera America’s study found a striking dearth of minorities in the administrative ranks of opera companies.
content: Opera has long grappled with a lack of racial diversity. Black, Latino and Asian singers have struggled to be cast in principal roles. Works by composers of color have rarely been performed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: The Tangled Tale of Eric Adams’s Apartment in Brooklyn
description: The mayor acknowledged that he does, in fact, still co-own the apartment, which he’d previously said was fully owned by a former partner.
content: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll look at the status of Mayor Eric Adams’s ownership of an apartment in Brooklyn. And, if you’ve ever wanted to own your very own subway car, one is about to be auctioned off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Ukraine’s president addresses African leaders.
content: Volodymyr Zelensky, the president of Ukraine, lobbied the African Union for support this week. He faced an uphill battle, addressing leaders who have close ties to Russia’s president, Vladimir Putin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew S. Lewis
title: The Ancient Art of Falconry at the Jersey Shore
description: How Ocean City cleared the gulls from its boardwalk — with falcons and hawks.
content: The war between humans and gulls in Ocean City, N.J., reached a turning point in 2019. In the years leading up to then, the town’s populations of great black-backed, ring-billed, laughing and herring gulls had become increasingly comfortable snatching beachgoers’ French fries, potato chips and other finger foods. One day that spring, Ocean City’s mayor, Jay Gillian, watched as a gull swooped into a stroller on the boardwalk and stole a slice of pizza from a toddler’s hands. The mayor swears he saw blood on the little girl’s face, though he admits it may have been sauce. The town’s brand — its slogan is “America’s Greatest Family Resort” — was being sullied.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Nayeri
title: The Athens Art Scene Goes Contemporary
description: While love for the Parthenon and all it represents remains strong, new art for the modern times is moving in.
content: ATHENS — On a recent afternoon, the Pennsylvania-born, Athens-based artist Jennifer Nelson toiled away at her new project in a spacious temporary studio. In a corner were overstuffed garbage bags of various colors whose contents would be used in her installation: “Waste (Inheritance).”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kalley Huang
title: The Rise of the 0.5 Selfie
description: These selfies, taken with an ultra-wide-angle lens, aren’t fussed over. Sometimes they are just “distorted and crazy.”
content: Julia Herzig, a 22-year-old from Larchmont, N.Y., has “an obsession.” It’s with taking a new kind of selfie — one that doesn’t exactly conform.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘The Human Trial’ Review: The Race for a Diabetes Cure
description: The married documentarians Lisa Hepner and Guy Mossman follow people with diabetes who put themselves forward as test subjects for a potential solution.
content: Imagine what a world without diabetes would look like. A vast reduction in pain, suffering, needless death. And, as a bonus, a significant drop in pharmaceutical ads, probably.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Critchley
title: Shakespeare Foreshadowed Our Current Malaise
description: With doubt and melancholy, Hamlet and Ophelia faced a reality as wrenching as our own.
content: This essay is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: What is reality? You can read more by visiting The Big Ideas series page.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What Fed Chair Powell has said about inflation, interest rates and the risk of a recession.
description: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, is appearing before the House financial services committee on Thursday, after testifying in the Senate on Wednesday about the central bank’s efforts to bring inflation under control. Notably, Mr. Powell said that while the Fed was trying to avoid it, a recession was “certainly a possibility.”
content: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, is appearing before the House financial services committee on Thursday, after testifying in the Senate on Wednesday about the central bank’s efforts to bring inflation under control. Notably, Mr. Powell said that while the Fed was trying to avoid it, a recession was “certainly a possibility.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall and Kris Rhim
title: In a first for bloodhounds, Trumpet wins Westminster.
description: Trumpet, 4, fended off a tough field of fellow champions, earning Best in Show out of the hound group.
content: TARRYTOWN, N.Y. — Trumpet, a magnificently be-wrinkled and be-jowled bloodhound from Illinois, won Best in Show at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show on Wednesday night, nosing out a tough crowd of competitors that included a fluffy Samoyed, a silky Maltese and an all-business German shepherd.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Police Officers Can’t Be Sued for Miranda Violations, Supreme Court Rules
description: In a second decision, the justices sided with a death row inmate who sought to be executed by firing squad rather than lethal injection.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Thursday that police officers may not be sued under a federal civil rights law for failing to administer the familiar warning required by the court’s 1966 decision in Miranda v. Arizona. The vote was 6 to 3, with the justices dividing along ideological lines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: Crypto Meltdown Forces a Rebranding
description: Digital currency’s hype men try to flip the script as Terra, Bitcoin and others fall off a cliff.
content: The cryptocurrency market is in a complete meltdown — which many are calling a “crypto winter.” But it’s more like an ice age, given that the market was roaring hot as recently as November, when the price of Bitcoin nearly hit $69,000. Today it’s hovering around $20,000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Netflix lays off another 300 employees.
description: The company is trying to reduce costs while it confronts declining subscriber growth.
content: Netflix laid off 300 people on Thursday, the second consecutive month that the streaming giant has cut staff as it confronts declining subscriber growth and a falling share price.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: G.O.P. Testimony at Jan. 6 Panel Exposes a Party Torn Between Truth and Trump
description: A Democratic-run committee relies on Republican witnesses to build the case against the former president — in searing detail.
content: As the House committee investigating the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol has built its public case that Donald J. Trump was at the center of an attempted coup, the panel has relied heavily on a seemingly unlikely stream of witnesses: Mr. Trump’s own advisers, his fellow Republicans and even his own family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: Government to Cancel $6 Billion in Student Loans for Defrauded Borrowers
description: Around 200,000 who sought relief after attending schools that the Education Department said showed signs of “substantial misconduct” will have their federal student loans wiped out.
content: Around 200,000 former students who attended schools that they said had defrauded them will have $6 billion in federal loans canceled under a sweeping settlement announced on Wednesday, the latest move by the Biden administration to address the student loan crisis by eliminating some debts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Need to Fix a Struggling Pitcher? Put Him in Dodger Blue.
description: Tony Gonsolin and Tyler Anderson — combined record: 17-0 — are the latest gambles to pay off for an organization that knows how to find what works.
content: CINCINNATI — No team loses more high-impact starting pitchers than the Los Angeles Dodgers. Yet no team consistently pitches so well. It is part of life in blue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Marcel the Shell With Shoes On’ Review: Bigger Isn’t Better
description: The one-inch-high shell voiced by Jenny Slate gets a feature-length vehicle, but the transition from YouTube fame is only partly successful.
content: When I was a kid, my sister and I had shelves filled with carefully arranged miniatures, ceramic animals and the tiny, delicate like. I never thought much about these displays, though now I see that collecting and ordering these diminutive emblems of the world is a way children express agency and control as they enter it. It’s no wonder that miniatures seem so charming: They’re time machines. The minuscule gives us access to “the enlarging gaze of the child,” as the philosopher Gaston Bachelard puts it in his book “The Poetics of Space.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Abandoned by Trump, Mo Brooks Is Now Open to Testifying About Jan. 6
description: Mr. Brooks lost his Alabama Senate runoff on Tuesday. He had been snubbed by former President Donald J. Trump, who withdrew his endorsement of Mr. Brooks and supported his rival.
content: Stinging from his resounding defeat in Alabama’s Republican runoff for the Senate on Tuesday and a snub from former President Donald J. Trump, Representative Mo Brooks now appears to be willing to testify as part of the Jan. 6 investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: From Russian Elites, No Sign of Broad Challenge to Putin
description: Many business owners and intellectuals fled Russia after the invasion of Ukraine, but others stayed behind, struggling to redefine their lives. Their diverging choices do not add up to a broad challenge to Vladimir Putin’s war.
content: Aleksandr Y. Lebedev looks like a prime target for sanctions meant to prompt Russia’s elites to turn against the Kremlin. He is a onetime billionaire and a former K.G.B. agent with deep connections both in Russia’s ruling class and in the West; his son owns British newspapers and is a member of the House of Lords.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Inside the Jan. 6 Hearings With Jamie Raskin: A Times Virtual Event
description: Join us on June 27 to hear a member of the House select committee investigating the attack talk about what the panel has learned, what the public hearings have accomplished and what’s to come.
content: On Jan. 6, 2021, a mob of supporters of President Donald J. Trump stormed the Capitol, disrupting the counting of electoral votes to confirm Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory in the 2020 election in a violent rampage that threatened to thwart the peaceful transfer of power. Now, through public hearings, a House select committee investigating the roots of the attack is sharing its findings about the events of that day and the monthslong campaign by Mr. Trump and his allies to overturn his defeat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Hoberman
title: Still Charming at 50: Luis Buñuel’s Greatest Hit
description: “The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeois” is a comedy of frustrations in which a sextet of super-civilized haute bourgeois repeatedly attempt and fail to sit down at dinner.
content: Luis Buñuel is a filmmaker with few peers and a unique career trajectory. A hardcore Surrealist in 1920s Paris and a propagandist for Republican Spain during the Civil War, Buñuel found refuge in the Mexican film industry before making a triumphant, late-life return to France and the art cinema pantheon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Barnard
title: Its ‘Demon’ Exorcised, a Floating Gay Party Series Returns
description: A year after a “demon twink” earned them outsize attention, the D.J. Ty Sunderland’s “Gayflower” parties kicked off a new season with a Spice Girls-themed event.
content: Ty Sunderland was pacing, his head bent intently over his phone. It was 5:52 p.m., eight minutes before 500 guests were expected to board the Circle Line Sightseeing Cruises boat where he was hosting a party on June 18, and the sound system had yet to be tuned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By José María León Cabrera and Megan Janetsky
title: Ecuador Roiled by Protests Set Off by Rising Fuel and Food Prices
description: The country’s capital has been virtually paralyzed by demonstrators, and the government says it has lost control of a small city in the Amazon to protesters wielding guns, spears and explosives.
content: QUITO, Ecuador — For more than a week, the Andean nation of Ecuador has been buffeted by at times violent protests over a spike in prices for fuel, food and other basic necessities, driven by a global inflation that is causing similar levels of frustration across Latin America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: Are Democrats Taking Working-Class Immigrants for Granted?
description: The win in Texas for Mayra Flores, a Republican who flipped her district, may be short lived but it shouldn’t be ignored.
content: Last week, Mayra Flores, a Republican candidate for Congress who was born in Mexico and immigrated to the United States at the age of 6, flipped a congressional seat in a region of the Rio Grande Valley of Texas that had voted Democrat for 150 years. Flores’s victory came with the usual bluster from the G.O.P. and all the head-scratching from the national media that accompanies rightward voting swings in any nonwhite population. “G.O.P. wins big in Rio Grande Valley district. Does it portend shift of Hispanic voters?” the Fort Worth Star-Telegram asked in a headline. The conservative National Review called Flores’s victory “An Earthquake in South Texas” and said that her win “portends a major shift in the major American political landscape.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: ‘Corsicana’ Review: Four Lost Hearts in the Heart of Texas
description: In a strange and beautiful new play by Will Arbery, finding happiness is a process of failing upward.
content: The difference between comedy and tragedy is often just a matter of timing. Bring the curtain down early enough and even “Macbeth” can have a happy ending; in the back story of a play full of laughs, you’ll often find a bucket of tears.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: Ohio State University Trademarks ‘The’
description: The trademark will offer the school, whose supporters famously emphasize the article in its name, some protection against unlicensed merchandise sellers.
content: Ohio State University has received a trademark for one of the most common words in the English language, one that the school’s supporters often forcefully emphasize when uttering its name: “The.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Heat records have fallen from Minneapolis to Macon, Ga.
description: Triple-digit heat is afflicting much of the country for a third straight week.
content: For the third week in a row, it’s hot out there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Naroditsky
title: Chess Replay: You Versus Karjakin
description: Take on Sergey Karjakin in a recreation of a World Championship game in New York, 2016. Solve for the best series of moves.
content: About Daniel
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Vedette’ Review: A Cow’s Trouble in Paradise
description: In this documentary, two French filmmakers meet a formidable Swiss cow and, under her impassive gaze, ruminate on her Alpine life.
content: Few places are lovelier for cows to ruminate in than the Valais in southern Switzerland. This alpine region’s most famous attraction is the Matterhorn, but it is also where you find a breed of cattle known as Hérens. There, on lush, steep slopes, these brown-black animals graze and graze some more, at times using their horns to plow into the dirt and one another.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: How an Abortion Ban Trapped a Tourist on Malta
description: Andrea Prudente, an American, developed pregnancy complications while on the island that could put her life at risk. But abortion is illegal there, and she is seeking a safe way to leave.
content: Andrea Prudente, a 38-year-old photographer who lives near Seattle, and her partner, Jay Weeldreyer, expected their trip to Malta to be a “babymoon” where they could connect with each other while enjoying the Mediterranean sun and local sights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Vatican Signals Pope Will Keep His Plan to Visit Canada for Apology
description: Francis plans to deliver a long-sought apology to Indigenous people for the church’s role in a residential school system where abuse was rife.
content: The Vatican released a detailed itinerary on Thursday for Pope Francis’s long-awaited trip to Canada, where he plans to apologize for the Roman Catholic church’s role in a residential school system for Indigenous children that eroded their culture and subjected many to sexual and physical abuse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: The New York gun law struck down on Thursday is still in force — for now.
description: The case will be sent back to a lower court — the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit — which is expected to send it back to Federal District Court in New York, a legal expert said.
content: The Supreme Court has ruled that New York’s law governing the carrying of handguns is unconstitutional, but the law is not yet off the books.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘Love & Gelato’ Review: A Young Girl, Transfigured by Italy
description: A mother’s final wish leads her daughter to retrace her Roman holiday in this lighthearted coming-of-age story.
content: For many American teenagers, college is the great undiscovered country. But in the romantic comedy, “Love & Gelato,” Lina (Susanna Skaggs) has just lost her beloved mother to cancer. Before she matriculates to her first year of university at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, she is obligated to live out her mother’s final wish for her. Her mother had a transformative trip to Italy in her youth, and her request is that Lina should follow in her footsteps. Cautious Lina can find a way to worry about anything, but magnanimously, she agrees to spend her summer in Rome.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Scientists Zero In on Origins of the Monkeypox Outbreak
description: Even as cases rise, genetic analysis suggests that the virus has been silently circulating in people since 2018.
content: When the first monkeypox cases were identified in early May, European health officials were stumped. The virus was not known to spread easily among people, let alone infect dozens — and soon hundreds — of young men.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Photosynthetic Process
description: Jeff Chen’s puzzle gives us twice the bang for our buck.
content: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Jeff Chen is back, and his puzzle is something to get excited about.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘Elvis’ Review: Shocking the King Back to Life
description: Austin Butler plays the singer, with Tom Hanks as his devilish manager, in Baz Luhrmann’s operatic, chaotic anti-biopic.
content: My first and strongest memory of Elvis Presley is of his death. He was only 42 but he already seemed, in 1977, to belong to a much older world. In the 45 years since, his celebrity has become almost entirely necrological. Graceland is a pilgrimage spot and a mausoleum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘Loot’ Review: Maya Rudolph Among the .001 Percent
description: In this Apple TV+ comedy from two “Parks and Recreation” veterans, a woman takes a journey of self-discovery with an $87 billion budget.
content: If you’re going to center a sitcom on a character who, post-divorce, is the third-richest woman in America, casting Maya Rudolph is a smart move.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy and Stanley Reed
title: ‘We are in a gas crisis.’ Germany raises emergency level.
description: Germany’s economy minister triggered the second stage of a contingency plan a week after Russia cut back on gas to Europe, sending prices soaring and raising fears of shortages.
content: Germany warned residents and businesses on Thursday that the country was in a natural gas crisis that could worsen in coming months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: In Remote Afghanistan, Scenes From a Deadly Earthquake
description: Officials said hopes of finding additional survivors were fading as they worked to bring aid to the injured in Paktika Province.
content: Hopes of finding additional survivors faded a day after a deadly earthquake struck eastern Afghanistan, with the worst damage apparently centered in remote, mountainous Paktika Province. Provincial officials said that at least 1,000 people had been killed, while the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs estimated that 770 people had been killed and 1,440 people had been injured in the 5.9-magnitude quake, and cautioned that those figures were very likely to rise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Lai and Emily Cochrane
title: Here’s what is in the Senate’s gun bill — and what was left out.
description: The Senate passed the most substantial gun safety measure in decades. It includes enhanced background checks for younger buyers and money for mental health and school safety.
content: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Thursday passed a bipartisan bill aimed at keeping guns out of the hands of dangerous people, the product of a compromise that could bring about the most substantial gun safety legislation in decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel and Andrew Jacobs
title: F.D.A. Orders Juul to Stop Selling E-Cigarettes
description: The agency ruled against the company’s application to stay on the market, a decisive blow to a once-popular vaping brand that appealed to teenagers.
content: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday ordered Juul to stop selling e-cigarettes on the U.S. market, a profoundly damaging blow to a once-popular company whose brand was blamed for the teenage vaping crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: I Cheated on My Wife. Why Won’t She Get Over It?
description: A reader is anguished to find that the road from confession to absolution isn’t always a direct path.
content: My wife and I have been married for eight years. We’re in our 30s and have two children. I love her; she’s my best friend. Unfortunately, I made a big mistake: I got drunk at a conference last month and slept with another woman. I swear it was a one-time thing and meant nothing to me! When I got home, I decided the right thing to do was to tell my wife what had happened, apologize and promise it would never happen again. I knew there might be fallout, but I had no idea she would be so upset. She has practically stopped talking to me and threatened to throw me out. I’ve apologized so many times. This is killing me! What more can I do?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: Delicious Reasons to Make Your Own Kimchi
description: Cooking with homemade vegetarian kimchi is a joy, at every stage of the fermentation.
content: One year, when I lived in Brooklyn, fuzzy perilla plants took over my building’s shared courtyard, so my husband washed and dried the abundance of leaves and stacked them with a quick kimchi sauce he’d puréed in the mini food processor. It was so simple, and so good, that we made more every few weeks until the plants died back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Would You Upload Your Consciousness to the Cloud?
description: Jennifer Egan, the author of “A Visit From the Goon Squad,” talks about her new book and social media’s “illusion of authenticity.”
content: Instagram, Twitter and TikTok can monopolize all of your time, driven by what the novelist Jennifer Egan calls humankind’s “ongoing hunger for authenticity.” But to Egan, social media is not a winning strategy for discovering what’s real or true: “Looking to the internet for authentic experience is just inherently a loser,” she says. The digital world, after all, offers only an “illusion of authenticity.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer, Adam Goldman and Maggie Haberman
title: Federal Authorities Search Home of Trump Justice Dept. Official
description: Investigators went to the suburban Washington home of Jeffrey Clark in connection with the sprawling inquiry into the Jan. 6 attack and the effort to overturn the 2020 election.
content: Federal investigators carried out an early-morning search on Wednesday at the home of Jeffrey Clark, a former Justice Department official, in connection with the department’s sprawling criminal inquiry into efforts to overturn the 2020 election, people familiar with the matter and an associate of Mr. Clark said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holland Cotter
title: For Black Artists, the Motivating Power of Melancholia
description: A group show at CCS Bard finds a positive value to looking inward, as it celebrates Black endurance.
content: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. — A racist attack on Black Americans, with the spectacle of real-time pain it carries, tends to make news. But the depression that racism itself generates — the dread, anger and despair that create a low-pressure area in the soul — goes pretty much unreported. It’s that chronic condition that forms the basic theme of “Black Melancholia,” a stirring group show that opens Saturday at the Hessel Museum of Art at Bard College here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Louisiana Nursing Home Owner Faces Cruelty Charges in Deadly Hurricane Evacuation
description: Bob Glynn Dean Jr. faces Medicaid fraud and other criminal charges after sending more than 800 residents to a squalid warehouse in August 2021, when Hurricane Ida pummeled the state, the authorities said.
content: The owner of seven nursing homes in Louisiana who sent more than 800 residents to a squalid warehouse lacking restrooms and proper medicine last year when Hurricane Ida battered the region was arrested on Wednesday on state fraud and cruelty charges, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Liz Cheney Encourages Wyoming Democrats to Change Parties to Vote for Her
description: Ms. Cheney, who faces a Trump-backed challenger, has begun mailing Wyoming Democrats instructions on how to change their party affiliation.
content: Representative Liz Cheney, a Republican of Wyoming whose polling remains far behind her Trump-endorsed primary challenger as her House committee’s Jan. 6 hearings continue, is urging Democrats in her home state to switch parties to support her in the Aug. 16 primary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Beware the Dangers of Sado-Monetarism
description: The Fed mustn’t get bullied into excessive harshness.
content: Sado-monetarism is having a moment. And one of the biggest risks now facing the U.S. economy is that it will have too much influence over policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Adam Kinzinger: A G.O.P. critic of Trump and his role on Jan. 6.
description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi appointed Mr. Kinzinger to the committee after rejecting two lawmakers chosen by Republican leaders who had defended President Donald J. Trump after the riot.
content: As lawmakers scrambled to evacuate the House chamber while a mob of pro-Trump supporters stormed the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, Representative Adam Kinzinger, Republican of Illinois, was blunt about what was unfolding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Jeffrey Rosen: The acting attorney general was pivotal in holding off Trump’s effort to install a loyalist atop the Justice Department.
description: Jeffrey A. Rosen led the Justice Department during the final month of the Trump administration, when President Donald J. Trump and his allies most aggressively pressed federal and state officials to undo his loss in the 2020 presidential election.
content: Jeffrey A. Rosen led the Justice Department during the final month of the Trump administration, when President Donald J. Trump and his allies most aggressively pressed federal and state officials to undo his loss in the 2020 presidential election.

title: Quotation of the Day: Jewish Political Clout at Risk In a Changing New York City
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, June 23, 2022.
content: “When I was in Congress, you could have a minyan in the New York delegation. We went from a minyan to a minority to hardly anybody.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: Deborah Birx Says Trump White House Asked Her to Weaken Covid Guidance
description: The former White House coronavirus coordinator, who became a controversial figure, said there was a consistent effort to stifle information as virus cases surged in late 2020.
content: WASHINGTON — Dr. Deborah L. Birx, President Donald J. Trump’s coronavirus response coordinator, told a congressional committee investigating the federal pandemic response that Trump White House officials asked her to change or delete parts of the weekly guidance she sent state and local health officials, in what she described as a consistent effort to stifle information as virus cases surged in the second half of 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: As Russian forces fortify a Ukrainian nuclear power plant, employees are fleeing repression, local officials say.
description: The Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant, Europe’s largest, lies in southern Ukraine in a strategically important spot.
content: Russian soldiers who control a giant nuclear power plant in Ukraine are detaining workers and subjecting them to brutal interrogations in a search for possible saboteurs, prompting many employees to leave and raising concerns about safety, Ukrainian officials say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Beavis and Butt-Head Do the Universe’ Review: Chortles in Space
description: Even though you can guess what these two characters will say as they’re sucked into a black hole, their cosmic adventure still delivers new laughs.
content: The future becomes the now in “Beavis and Butt-Head Do the Universe,” the animated comedy directed by John Rice and Albert Calleros, and streaming on Paramount+. The year is 1998, and through an incendiary set of circumstances, the endlessly chortling animated MTV miscreants originally created (and still voiced) by Mike Judge are brought on to help engineer a NASA space station docking mission. In their own minds, their tale is one of “two heroes on a quest to score.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Dwyer
title: Lidia Yuknavitch Writes to Break With the ‘Tyranny’ of the Past
description: Her latest novel, “Thrust,” relies on time travel and characters from society’s margins to explore the idea that “it might be possible to change the stories we tell ourselves about who we are.”
content: It was a sea turtle that changed everything for Lidia Yuknavitch. At 13, she spent time in Trinidad while her father, an architect, designed a shopping center there. One day, while floating in the Gulf of Paria, she said, a child-size turtle sidled up to her and placed its flipper directly over her heart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: ‘It’s ridiculous’: Relatives of Buffalo massacre victims express anger at the decision.
description: The city is still mourning 10 people who were killed by a gunman at a grocery store last month.
content: As the Supreme Court struck down a New York State law that strictly limited the carrying of handguns, the decision prompted frustration among some in Buffalo, the state’s second-largest city where 10 people were killed in gunfire at a grocery store last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Soccer Mommy Summons a ‘Tidal Wave’ of Feelings
description: The songwriter Sophie Allison finds new sonic frontiers alongside Oneohtrix Point Never on her third studio album, “Sometimes, Forever.”
content: “I don’t know how to feel things small,” Sophie Allison, the songwriter behind Soccer Mommy, sings in “Still,” which closes her third studio album, “Sometimes, Forever.” She continues, “It’s a tidal wave or nothing at all.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: App Rules Are Twisted to Absurdity
description: It’s not just you — what you can buy on your phone makes less and less sense.
content: Apps have become a huge economy, but the rules that govern them are nearly impossible to understand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: When, Exactly, Did Mount Vesuvius Erupt?
description: From tracing ashes to Greece to analyzing autumnal fruit found in Pompeii, a new study places the eruption in October, not August.
content: ROME — Traditionally, it has been held that the lives of ancient Pompeiians were tragically cut short on Aug. 24, A.D. 79, when Mount Vesuvius unleashed its fury, smothering Pompeii and other cities along its perimeter with volcanic debris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Michael Simon Johnson, Carlos Prieto, Clare Toeniskoetter, Asthaa Chaturvedi, M.J. Davis Lin, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: The Supreme Court Case That Could Doom U.S. Climate Goals
description: The government’s power to tackle pollution is not the only question at stake in a potentially far-reaching lawsuit.
content: While coming rulings on abortion and guns have garnered lots of attention, the Supreme Court is also set to make another major decision in a less-publicized suit involving climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: In New Orleans, Time-Tested Charms and Some Bright New Baubles
description: Immersive art, bespoke hotels and restaurants that range from Creole to a ‘tropical roadhouse’ are only a few of the offerings awaiting visitors.
content: Even for a city like New Orleans, which has been bouncing back from calamities viral, meteorological and otherwise for three centuries, the last couple of years have been rough. But today, the most freewheeling city in the nation is strutting forward with a sense of relief and renewed confidence, seducing visitors with time-tested charms and a few bright new baubles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Austria quietly discards a vaccine mandate that it never enforced.
description: The mandate threatened fines for adults who chose not to be vaccinated, but the government held off enforcement after a panel determined that the Omicron variant was less of a threat than Delta.
content: BERLIN — Austria, the only Western nation to introduce a general vaccine mandate against the coronavirus, is abandoning the policy a few months after it decided to hold off enforcement, the country’s health minister said Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman
title: This Teen Already Broke Some of Usain Bolt’s Records. He’s Getting Faster.
description: Erriyon Knighton, just out of high school, has already lowered Bolt’s world junior record in the 200 meters. “It’s almost like he’s a pogo stick,” Knighton’s coach said.
content: TAMPA, Fla. — When Erriyon Knighton, a few months past his 18th birthday, became the fourth-fastest 200-meter runner in history on April 30, his fellow sprinter Michael Cherry tweeted in amazement, “That boy got algebra on Monday.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cora Engelbrecht and Farnaz Fassihi
title: Iran Dismisses Revolutionary Guards’ Powerful Intelligence Chief
description: Hossein Taeb, a top official in the force, was transferred to a lower ranking job amid an escalation in Israel’s shadow war with Iran.
content: Iran has dismissed the longstanding intelligence chief of the Revolutionary Guards force, considered one of the country’s most powerful figures, as concerns mount over Israel’s covert war on Iran’s defense systems and its nuclear program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: A Year Later, Some Republicans Second-Guess Boycotting the Jan. 6 Panel
description: The decision by Representative Kevin McCarthy not to appoint Republicans to the committee has given Democrats the chance to set out an uninterrupted narrative.
content: Follow live updates on the House committee hearing on the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: June 23, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, June 23, 2022.
content: An article on Wednesday about a rent increase of at least 3.25 percent for rent-stabilized homes in New York City misstated how Christina Smyth, a representative of landlords on the Rent Guidelines Board, voted. She voted in favor of the proposal that passed, not against it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Hugh McElhenny, Elusive Hall of Fame Halfback, Is Dead at 93
description: Known as the King, he was a thrilling figure on the field, twisting and turning as he frustrated defenders on his circuitous romps to the end zone.
content: Hugh McElhenny, a Hall of Fame halfback who was known as the King for his thrilling, high-stepping prowess in the football world of the 1950s, first with the University of Washington and then with the San Francisco 49ers, died on June 17 at his home in Henderson, Nev. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt
title: 5 Takeaways From Thursday’s Hearing by the Jan. 6 Committee
description: The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack laid out in detail how President Donald J. Trump and his allies sought to install a loyalist atop the Justice Department.
content: The House committee’s fifth hearing focused on President Donald J. Trump’s attempts to harness the powers of the Justice Department to remain in office. Relying on testimony of three former top Justice Department officials who played central roles in the episode, the committee laid out in detail how Mr. Trump and his allies in the department and on Capitol Hill sought to install a loyalist atop the Justice Department and reverse the election results from a key swing state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thinzar Shunlei Yi
title: The U.S. Can Put Sanctions on Russian Gas to Punish Putin. I’m Asking It to Do the Same in Myanmar.
description: President Biden should cut off the gas revenues that fund Myanmar’s junta.
content: Myanmar’s modern history has been marked by colonial exploitation, military repression, violence and democracy denied. Grass-roots activists like me and thousands before me have dedicated our lives and sacrificed our safety to change this. But over the past year, an even deeper darkness has descended.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Hopler and Victoria Chang
title: Poem: ‘love & the memory of it’
description: Jay Hopler died last week. Illness streaks across this poem from his final collection — but also love.
content: I always remember these lines in Jay Hopler’s debut book of poems, “Green Squall”: “Being born is a shame–/But it’s not so bad, as journeys go. … ” Sixteen years later comes Hopler’s third book of poems, one that documents his journey on the other end of a life, as he grapples with a terminal illness. Illness streaks across these new poems, toppling them with sonic devastation. The ending of this poem speaks for itself, but its sadness intermingles with the speaker’s love for the “atomic girl” and the way her laughter “echoed off the rocks.” Hopler died on June 15, 2022 at the age of 51. Selected by Victoria Chang
source.name: The New York Times

title: Judge John Hodgman on Phish Shows
description: A woman’s fiancé wants to drag her along. Must she go?
content: Rachel writes: My fiancé, Steve, wants me to go to a Phish show — he has been to more than 60 — but every time he turns on Phish, it puts me to sleep. I don’t want to pay for an expensive nap. Please order that he stops asking me to go to his hippie festivals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘The Black Phone’ Review: The Dead Have Your Number
description: Ethan Hawke plays the big bad in this 1970s-set child-abduction thriller.
content: More touching than terrifying, Scott Derrickson’s “Black Phone” is less a horror movie than a coming-of-age ghost story. In place of gouting gore and surging fright, this enjoyable adaptation of Joe Hill’s 2005 short story has an almost contemplative tone, one that drains its familiar horror tropes — a masked psychopath, communications from beyond the grave — of much of their chill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gregory Schmidt
title: Cost of Owning a Home Surges Above the Cost of Renting One
description: A new report shows that having a mortgage is far more expensive than having a lease, a disparity that is helping to cool a red-hot housing market.
content: Housing costs, pushed higher by soaring home prices and rising mortgage rates, outpaced rental costs in April, making owning a home more expensive on a monthly basis than renting one, according to a new report.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes
title: A study of the war details Russia’s many failed cyberattacks, but also its power in disinformation.
description: WASHINGTON — A new examination of how Russia used its cybercapabilities in the first months of the war in Ukraine contains a number of surprises: Moscow conducted more cyberattacks than was realized at the time to bolster its invasion, but more than two-thirds of them failed, echoing its poor performance on the physical battlefield.
content: WASHINGTON — A new examination of how Russia used its cybercapabilities in the first months of the war in Ukraine contains a number of surprises: Moscow conducted more cyberattacks than was realized at the time to bolster its invasion, but more than two-thirds of them failed, echoing its poor performance on the physical battlefield.

title: ‘Olga’ Review: Tough Balancing Act for a Ukrainian Girl in Exile
description: Elie Grappe’s quietly poignant film about a young gymnast finds her torn between her passion and the violence gripping her country — in 2013.
content: Completed in early 2021 and set the decade before, Elie Grappe’s confident first scripted feature, “Olga,” wasn’t meant to be about Russia’s continuing assault on Ukraine. It’s impossible today, however, to watch the film, about a tough but vulnerable young Ukrainian gymnast in exile, through another lens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: You Don’t Need a Microscope to See the Biggest Bacteria Ever Found
description: Researchers found bacterial cells so large they are easily visible to the naked eye, challenging ideas about how large microbes can get.
content: In a Caribbean mangrove forest, scientists have discovered a species of bacteria that grows to the size and shape of a human eyelash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: At 10, ‘Dragons Love Tacos’ is Still Flying Off Shelves
description: Adam Rubin and Daniel Salmieri teamed up on a picture book about imaginary creatures and hot salsa. It took on a life of its own.
content: The latest Amazon reviews of “Dragons Love Tacos” are less than stellar. “Seriously, a fire breathing dragon doesn’t like spicy tacos???!!!???” writes one reader — or, more likely, a parent or caregiver of a reader, since we’re talking about a picture book.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: In One Day, Washington Goes in Two Directions on Guns
description: The Supreme Court delivered a victory for gun rights, while the Senate passed a gun control bill for the first time in decades.
content: WASHINGTON — The nation’s capital, so often a backdrop for inaction, had seldom witnessed anything quite like it — two branches of government splintering in opposite directions on guns, one of the country’s most divisive issues, in the space of a single day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei and Mike Baker
title: One Button Could Have ‘Saved More Lives’ in Florida Condo Collapse
description: Seven minutes elapsed between the initial rumblings and the collapse of Champlain Towers South in Surfside. But a security guard didn’t know how to activate the building’s warning system.
content: SURFSIDE, Fla. — The thunderous bang that jolted Jonah Handler and his mother in the middle of the night last June was followed by silence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘First Person'
title: Why One Progressive Public Defender Hoped for an N.R.A. Victory
description: Sharone Mitchell Jr. was “never a gun guy.” So why did he side with the N.R.A. in the Supreme Court’s latest case on gun rights?
content: Hours after this episode was released, the Supreme Court overturned New York State’s gun-permitting system — a decision with major implications for the regulation of guns outside the home. The case was, unsurprisingly, backed by the National Rifle Association. But it also found supporters in typically liberal public defenders, like Sharone Mitchell Jr.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: Eric Greitens to Face New G.O.P. Attacks in Missouri Senate Race
description: Many Republicans worry that Greitens, who has a history of personal scandals, could jeopardize what is most likely a safe G.O.P. seat. Now efforts to block him are gaining steam.

title: Eric Greitens’s Plug for Political Violence Is No Joke
description: His “RINO hunting” ad shows how chillingly far Republicans will go.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘Flux Gourmet’ Review: Mastering the Art of Fringe Cooking
description: Peter Strickland’s latest film is a speculative comedy about art, desire and gastrointestinal discomfort.
content: What if the primary sensory goal of cooking were to stimulate the ears? What if you experienced a movie through your nostrils and taste buds, or felt it in your gut? These bizarre, intriguing questions are part of the foundation, the spine — the sofrito — of “Flux Gourmet,” the fifth feature by the British writer-director Peter Strickland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Strugatz
title: When Did Perfume Stop Being About Sex?
description: Its decades-long grip on the global fragrance industry is slipping. You can thank changing views on sexual orientation and gender.
content: When a new Yves Saint Laurent perfume came out in 2001, Tom Ford, the creative director of the house at the time, threw a sensational party at the Paris Stock Exchange, where he put a gaggle of practically nude models on display in a giant plexiglass container. The fragrance was called Nu, French for “nude.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Burke
title: Performing and Creating as Equals Across the Age Gap
description: “It’s not really like we’re dancing. It’s more just like we’re moving,” Heera Gandhu, 13, says of his collaboration with the choreographer Mariana Valencia at Abrons.
content: The sound of heavy footfalls filled a studio at Abrons Arts Center on a recent afternoon, as the choreographer Mariana Valencia and her young collaborator, Heera Gandhu, walked decisively around the room. With their arms raised to one side and hands gnarled into claws, they called to mind the classic move from Michael Jackson’s “Thriller,” but their faces betrayed little emotion. The recognizable gesture, combined with their even-keeled energy, managed to say “horror movie” and “postmodern dance” at the same time, a fitting encapsulation of their interests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: She Fainted During the World Championships. Her Coach Came to the Rescue.
description: Anita Alvarez, an American artistic swimmer, lost consciousness while performing her solo routine in Budapest. She was “fine” afterward, her coach said.
content: As the American artistic swimmer Anita Alvarez sank slowly to the bottom of the pool at the world championships in Budapest on Wednesday, her coach, Andrea Fuentes, quickly scanned the pool deck and made a split-second decision: She dived in to save her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Manseau
title: The Myth of the ‘Good Guy With a Gun’ Has Religious Roots
description: God and guns have become strangely intertwined.
content: Is our gun problem a God problem?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valeriya Safronova
title: American Girl Doll Jokes Are All the Rage
description: The “We need an American Girl doll who …” memes suggests alternate story lines for the popular toys and provide sly social criticism.
content: Since 1986, American Girl dolls like Molly McIntire, recognizable by her braids and round glasses, and Josefina Montoya, dressed in a long red-and-blue skirt and moccasins, have transported children who played with them to Illinois during World War II or to what is now New Mexico, during the early 19th century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni, David F. Gallagher and Jenny Gross
title: Netflix Needs Some Help With Ads
description: The streaming service is reportedly talking to Comcast and Google as it seeks to create an ad-supported offering.
content: Reed Hastings, Netflix’s co-founder, once dismissed the idea of putting ads on the streaming service as a nonstarter. Then, this year, the company posted its first subscriber loss in more than a decade, causing its stock to nosedive. Now, the company is talking to Comcast and Google to help it with the details of a plan to bring an ad-supported offering to its service, The Wall Street Journal reported yesterday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Advisers to the C.D.C. recommend Moderna’s vaccine for children and teens aged 6 through 17.
description: Pfizer-BioNTech’s Covid vaccine has been available to children 5 through 15 since last year and to Americans 16 and older since late 2020.
content: Advisers to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Thursday voted unanimously to recommend Moderna’s coronavirus vaccine for children and adolescents aged 6 through 17 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed and Melissa Eddy
title: Russia is crimping gas flows just as Europe is racing to stock up for winter.
description: Germany’s largest storage chamber for natural gas stretches underneath a swath of farmland the size of nine soccer fields in the western part of the country. The bucolic area has become a kind of battlefield in Europe’s effort to defend itself against a looming gas crisis driven by Russia.

author: By Reyhan Harmanci
title: When Raw Emotion Goes Viral
description: In the wake of a mass shooting, reaction videos fill a desperate need.
content: From the moment reports of a shooter in a Texas elementary school hit social media, you knew to expect certain beats. First, the errant clips from people near the scene; then the early, erroneous news stories; then the timeline filling in, hour by hour, as national media jostled with local outlets for information. Within a day, you would see the stomach-churning clips of survivors, bystanders, parents, followed by the heartbreaking photos and details of victims — which, for the town of Uvalde, meant reading obituaries of fourth graders, where in place of adult achievements stood details like: “Her favorite color was sage green.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Monika Pronczuk
title: European leaders are meeting today to decide on granting Ukraine E.U. candidate status.
description: Their approval would allow Ukraine to be a candidate to join the bloc, starting what could be a long road.
content: BRUSSELS — European Union leaders will meet on Thursday to put Ukraine on a path toward joining the bloc, signaling to the embattled nation — and to Russia — that they expect Ukraine to win the benefits of being in the club, even if it takes a decade or longer to fully join.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: South Africa’s Corruption Inquiry Leaves Few of the Nation’s Powerful Unscathed
description: The final portion of a three-year investigation reported graft on a massive scale under former President Jacob Zuma, but also found the current president’s actions wanting.
content: JOHANNESBURG — The final findings of a three-year inquiry into deep-rooted corruption in South Africa were released Wednesday, part of a roughly 5,000-page report that heavily implicated the country’s former president, Jacob Zuma, but also found fault with how current President Cyril Ramaphosa handled allegations of misconduct.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Katie Benner
title: Jan. 6 Panel Outlines Trump’s Bid to Coerce Justice Dept. Officials
description: The committee’s fifth hearing this month vividly depicted a department that worked frantically to stave off a constitutional crisis under pressure from the president.
content: WASHINGTON — The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol painted a vivid picture on Thursday of how former President Donald J. Trump directed a wide-ranging bid to strong-arm the Justice Department into overturning the 2020 election, the most brazen attempt by a sitting president since Watergate to manipulate the nation’s law enforcement apparatus to keep himself in power.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Zara Home Collaboration With Vincent Van Duysen
description: Plus: bungalows near a national park, a new sushi restaurant in Manhattan and more recommendations from T Magazine.
content: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we share things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Reporting on the Future, Now
description: Cade Metz, a technology correspondent for The Times, shares how he approaches his reporting and what excites him most about the beat.
content: In labs across the world, scientists are developing the power of quantum mechanics, a field of physics that behaves unlike anything we experience in our everyday lives. In 2019, Google announced that its quantum computer had achieved “quantum supremacy,” which could allow new kinds of computers to perform calculations at what were once unimaginable speeds. Other companies and research labs are exploring techniques like quantum teleportation, which sends data between locations without moving the matter that holds it — a concept that Albert Einstein had deemed impossible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Colter Walls
title: What Is American Music? Three Classical Albums Offer Answers.
description: Recordings by the violinists Daniel Hope and Johnny Gandelsman, as well as by PUBLIQuartet, wrestle with the country’s past and present.
content: What is American classical music, exactly? When crafting their answers, programmers have historically chosen one of two approaches: cautious, piecemeal efforts or risky, all-in-one fusion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: The White House Covid czar says he’s still optimistic about more aid, despite recent Republican objections.
description: Billions of dollars in new emergency aid to fight Covid have been stalled in Congress, and Republicans on Capitol Hill have made clear the aid package is all but dead.
content: President Biden’s coronavirus response coordinator said Thursday that he remained optimistic that Congress would approve billions of dollars in new emergency aid to fight Covid, even as Republicans on Capitol Hill have made clear the aid package is all but dead.

content: Everybody has a personal Elvis. He is there for us all, lodged in the collective unconscious, one of few humans who can legitimately be termed an icon, although it is not always certain of what.

author: By Erica L. Green
title: New Biden Rules Would Bar Discrimination Against Transgender Students
description: The proposed rules would prohibit discrimination based on gender identity, among other things; they set up a clash with state lawmakers and conservative groups.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration on Thursday proposed new rules governing how schools must respond to sex discrimination, rolling back major parts of a Trump administration policy that narrowed the scope of campus sexual misconduct investigations and cementing the rights of transgender students into law.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: “Closeness is impossible between an artist and a critic,” The New Yorker’s great art critic Peter Schjeldahl wrote a few years ago, in an article that acknowledged at least fleetingly that closeness had likewise proved challenging at times between the author — a recovering alcoholic — and his daughter, the writer Ada Calhoun, who was 16 when Schjeldahl got sober. (“Let’s see if I get this straight,” she told him then, in his recollection. “Now you want to be my dad?”)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Stephen Colbert Taunts Ron Johnson for Faking It
description: Colbert said that the Wisconsin senator tried to avoid talking to reporters after Tuesday’s Jan. 6 hearing, “but like most things, he’s not very good at that.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Najim Rahim
title: In a stricken village in Paktika, ‘Everyone here cried from night to morning.’
description: Zakiullah Atal, a religious scholar, was asleep at the Islamic seminary where he works in the Gayan district of Afghanistan’s Paktika Province when he was awakened early on Wednesday by the sound of his students shouting.
content: Zakiullah Atal, a religious scholar, was asleep at the Islamic seminary where he works in the Gayan district of Afghanistan’s Paktika Province when he was awakened early on Wednesday by the sound of his students shouting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘Wildhood’ Review: On the Road, Sorting Out Growing Up
description: Three young men explore their Indigenous heritage and questions about their gender and sexual identity in this film.
content: In the tender coming-of-age tale “Wildhood,” Link (Phillip Lewitski) is a young man of Mi’kmaq heritage who journeys across rural areas in search of the mother he hardly knew. The movie was written and directed by the Nova Scotian filmmaker Bretten Hannam, who is Two-Spirit and nonbinary, and their camera intimately observes Link as he slowly casts off the protective shield he once needed to survive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Biden’s Inner Circle Debates Future of Offshore Drilling
description: Top White House officials have assumed control over a sensitive blueprint, expected by June 30, laying out future oil and gas drilling leases in the outer continental shelf.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s top aides are weighing whether to ban new oil and gas drilling off America’s coasts, a move that would elate climate activists but could leave the administration vulnerable to Republican accusations that it is exacerbating an energy crunch as gas prices soar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: Fed Says Stress Tests Show Big Banks Can Withstand a Severe Recession
description: The annual tests hold new significance as inflation persists and signs of a coming downturn continue to accumulate.
content: The largest banks in the United States are well capitalized and could weather a severe economic downturn, Federal Reserve officials announced on Thursday after an annual review of the big banks’ resilience. The tests took on new significance as some economic indicators, like slowing home sales and rising interest rates, appeared to increase the likelihood of a recession in the near future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum, Safiullah Padshah, Kyle Crichton and Kiana Hayeri
title: In Afghan Quake: ‘I Did Not Expect to Survive’
description: As aid workers and volunteers rushed to help, survivors told harrowing tales of death and destruction.
content: SHARANA, Afghanistan — As the earth shook, she said, speaking through her tears, she felt the walls of the room collapsing on her. Then everything went dark. When Hawa, a 30-year-old mother of six, regained consciousness, she was choking on dust, and struggled to make sense of the scene around her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: This Wimbledon Champion Never Had a Tennis Lesson
description: Dick Savitt, the first Jewish player to win the English tournament, has spent his life helping other athletes, including Arthur Ashe.
content: In 1951 Dick Savitt, a self-taught tennis player, stunned the world by winning both the Australian Open and Wimbledon, becoming the first Jewish champion of both vaunted tournaments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: Never Mind Your Wallet. Armed Robbers Want Your French Bulldog.
description: The popular breed has become one of the most expensive in the United States. Some owners have started carrying guns for protection.
content: ELK GROVE, Calif. — The French bulldog business is booming for Jaymar Del Rosario, a breeder whose puppies can sell for tens of thousands of dollars. When he leaves the house to meet a buyer, his checklist includes veterinary paperwork, a bag of puppy kibble and his Glock 26.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Schaefer
title: Velcro or Snaps? The ABC’s of Stripping for a Cause
description: Broadway Bares began as a response to the AIDS crisis. Thirty years later, the one-night-only burlesque spectacle remains a potent, frisky fund-raiser.
content: Jerry Mitchell was a 32-year-old Broadway hoofer causing a sensation each night by dancing nearly naked in “The Will Rogers Follies” when he had an idea: To shake his bare bum for a good cause.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catrin Einhorn
title: Biden Administration Tosses Trump Definition of ‘Habitat’ for Endangered Species
description: The Trump administration’s definition was at odds with the conservation purposes of the Endangered Species Act, wildlife officials said.
content: The Biden administration is throwing out the definition of “habitat” for endangered animals, returning to an understanding that existed before the government under President Donald J. Trump shrank the areas that could be protected for animals under threat of extinction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser
title: Prosecutors Ask That Ghislaine Maxwell Spend at Least 30 Years in Prison
description: Ms. Maxwell, who will be sentenced next week, showed an “utter lack of remorse” for helping Jeffrey Epstein recruit and abuse girls, federal prosecutors told a judge.
content: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan, writing that Ghislaine Maxwell had made the choice to conspire with Jeffrey Epstein for years, “working as partners in crime and causing devastating harm to vulnerable victims,” asked a judge on Wednesday night to sentence her to at least 30 years in prison.
source.name: The New York Times
