author: By Lola Fadulu
title: Eric Adams Stopped Enforcing Vaccine Mandate for New York City Businesses
description: The mayor’s office said it had no plans to begin inspecting businesses or begin fining those that are not in compliance.
content: Mayor Eric Adams of New York City has not enforced the city’s coronavirus vaccine mandate for employees at private businesses, and has no plans to begin inspecting businesses or begin fining those that are not in compliance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Greer Donley, Rachel Rebouché and David S. Cohen
title: How to Make Abortion Pills More Available for a Post-Roe World
description: Medication abortion isn’t a magic solution to the likely end of Roe. But it can blunt the fallout.
content: Before Roe v. Wade was decided in 1973, millions of Americans found ways around state laws so that they could get abortions. Too many were forced to rely on unsafe methods — whether that was a “back alley” provider or a knitting needle at home — resulting in injury, infertility and even death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Faber
title: For a Kyiv Techno Collective, ‘Now Everything Is About Politics’
description: Since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, the team behind Cxema parties have shifted its focus, but political engagement is nothing new for the artists.
content: When Slava Lepsheiev founded the Ukrainian techno collective Cxema in 2014, “I thought it should be outside politics and just a place where people can be happy and dance,” the D.J., 40, said in a recent video interview from Kyiv.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: ‘We (Nous)’ Review: This Is Us
description: Alice Diop’s observational documentary is a beautiful, loose-limned portrait of Paris’s suburbs.
content: Alice Diop’s documentary “We,” a beautiful, loose-limned portrait of Paris’s “banlieues” or suburbs, brought to my mind the words of the Senegalese director Ousmane Sembène. When asked if his films are understood in Europe, he replied, “Europe is not my center. Europe is on the outskirts.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Tang
title: Maine’s End Run Around the Supreme Court Offers States a Blueprint on Guns
description: The move in a religion case offers hopes to those worried about the dominance of the court’s conservative majority.
content: What a week so far for conservatives. On Tuesday, the Supreme Court struck down a Maine law that prohibited religious private schools from receiving taxpayer dollars. And on Thursday, it invalidated a New York State gun safety law limiting the public carry of firearms. The outcome in these cases was not surprising. The court has ruled in favor of religious litigants in an overwhelming number of cases, and the gun case’s outcome was clear from the oral argument before the justices in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: Molière, Turning 400, Can Still Surprise
description: In an anniversary year for the playwright, new productions in the Paris region show why his work still appeals to myriad audiences.
content: PARIS — “I’m in shock,” a teenage boy sitting near me declared when the lights went up on a recent performance of Molière’s “The Forced Marriage” at the Comédie-Française, France’s oldest theater company. “It was really sexual,” one of his schoolmates told her friends on the way out. “It’s not the kind of stuff you should show.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Fifty Years On, Title IX’s Legacy Includes Its Durability
description: From 1972 to 1973, the United States considered three landmark changes to protect women’s rights. Fifty years later, only one is likely to remain.
content: It took just 37 words to change the course of education for millions of women and girls in the United States. Yet the succinct language in Title IX, the landmark education law that was signed in 1972, has origins in even fewer characters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Michael Levenson
title: First Step Toward Ukraine Joining E.U. Signals Solidarity Amid War
description: As Russia’s brutal offensive squeezes defenders in eastern Ukraine, Europe’s leaders, in a rebuke to Moscow, made a move they would have rejected before the invasion.
content: BRUSSELS — The European Union officially made Ukraine a candidate for membership on Thursday, signaling in the face of a devastating Russian military onslaught that it sees Ukraine’s future as lying in an embrace of the democratic West.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed officials pledge ‘unconditional’ dedication to lowering inflation.
description: Central bankers are taking aggressive action to lower price increases. On Thursday, they signaled a willingness to keep going, despite the economic pain it could cause.
content: Federal Reserve officials on Thursday signaled a deep commitment to wrestling down the highest inflation in more than four decades, even as supply disruptions that are largely outside their control help push prices sharply higher.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Proudfoot
title: When the Backlash Came for Title IX, She Fought Back
description: Throughout her life, Representative Patsy Mink challenged the status quo. As a leading advocate of Title IX, she defended the bill against those who sought to weaken it.
content: Fifty years ago, on June 23, President Richard Nixon signed Title IX, the 37-word snippet within the Educational Amendments of 1972 that prohibits discrimination on the basis of sex “under any education program or activity receiving federal financial assistance.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: A Delayed Ending to Game 4 Has Instant Aftershocks
description: Players and officials needed an extra moment to realize Colorado had scored in overtime. Now, Tampa Bay trails 3-1 and needs to quickly move on from a goal it believes should not have counted.
content: TAMPA, Fla. — The game that ushered the Colorado Avalanche to the precipice of winning their first Stanley Cup in over two decades had ended a minute or two earlier, and the Hockey Hall of Famer at the back of the freight elevator at Amalie Arena stared straight ahead as it descended the seven flights to ice level.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Apples’ Review: Forget Me Not
description: Amnesia strikes individuals at random in this absurdist dramedy from Greece, which may be too deadpan for its own good.
content: Firmly in the tradition of the “Greek Weird Wave” that most viewers associate with the films of Yorgos Lanthimos, “Apples” is a deadpan dramedy with an eerily familiar dystopian premise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jin Yu Young
title: Korean currency falls to 13-year low amid global recession fears.
description: South Korea’s export-driven economy makes it particularly sensitive to conditions in the global economy.
content: SEOUL — The South Korean won hit its lowest point against the U.S. dollar in nearly 13 years on Thursday, opening at 1,299 won and weakening to more than 1,300 in intraday trading.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Vanhoenacker
title: A Gay Pilot Reflects on What Travel Means to Queer Folks
description: As Pride is celebrated around the world, a traveler recalls the cities that helped shape his identity and dreams.
content: “Bonjour,” says the barista as I reach the head of the line. I order a coffee and croissant, then take a moment to remind myself which country this cafe is in — a familiar quandary for long-haul pilots — and to confirm that the bank note I pull from my pocket is Canadian. Then I mangle a “merci” and step between the tables, each crowded with young tech workers speaking in euphonic blends of French and English, to a stool by the window overlooking the crowded street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Lai
title: Richard Donoghue: The Justice Department’s No. 2 official told Trump that his voter fraud claims had no merit.
description: Mr. Donoghue has testified that, in a phone call, the president ordered him and the acting attorney general to simply “say that the election was corrupt” and “leave the rest to me.”
content: Richard P. Donoghue, who served as acting deputy attorney general in the Trump administration, was a crucial witness to President Donald J. Trump’s efforts to use the Justice Department to overturn the 2020 election results, and one of several officials there who pumped the brakes on the plan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno
title: 7-Eleven Franchisee Who Rebelled Against Company Loses in Court
description: Mitoshi Matsumoto, who defied corporate edicts by closing for a few hours every night, was ordered by a judge to hand over his store near Osaka, Japan, and pay damages to the corporate giant.
content: OSAKA, Japan — Mitoshi Matsumoto, the man who has waged a David-and-Goliath campaign against the Japanese convenience store giant 7-Eleven, stood in front of a roomful of the company’s franchisees on Thursday, bowed deeply and apologized.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Your Friday Briefing: After the Quake
description: Afghans search for survivors and China faces twin extreme weather crises.
content: Afghan officials said that rescue efforts were winding down after a 5.9-magnitude earthquake, which struck early Wednesday morning and was believed to have killed more than 1,000 people.

title: The Dream’s Clean-Slate Strategy Made Space for a Star: Rhyne Howard

content: The Atlanta Dream were looking to start over.

title: What Are the Dirtiest Beaches in California?
description: Swimming in polluted beaches increases the chance of skin rashes and infections.
content: I’ll start with the good news: 94 percent of California’s beaches logged clean water-quality scores in 2021 between April and October, the months when we’re most likely to take a dip in the ocean.
source.name: The New York Times

title: New Hampshire Poll Points to Trouble for Trump; Growing Support for DeSantis
description: Support for Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida to be the party’s next presidential nominee grew to 39 percent from 18 percent last fall.
content: A new Granite State Poll of likely Republican primary voters in New Hampshire signals weakening support for former President Donald J. Trump as the party’s presidential nominee in 2024 — and growing strength for Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘Trevor: The Musical’ Review: He’s Coming Out
description: A bullied eighth grader learns to shine in this filmed version of the stage musical streaming on Disney+.
content: Trevor is a fictional boy with real world impact. In 1995, “Trevor,” a 23-minute film about the bullied eighth grader, won the Academy Award for live action short; three years later, its creators founded the Trevor Project, a crisis intervention organization for L.G.B.T.Q. youth, and recently allowed the story to be reworked by the stage director Marc Bruni into an adamantly chipper Off Broadway musical that ran last fall for eight weeks and lives on in Robin Abrams’s energetic and tonally discordant filmed recording.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Chernobyl: The Lost Tapes’ Review: Excavating Images From the Fallout
description: This archival documentary uses footage from the former Soviet Union to reconstruct the nuclear disaster from the perspectives of people who were present.
content: Drawing on archival visual material from the former Soviet Union and a mix of old and contemporary interviews, the tense documentary “Chernobyl: The Lost Tapes” reconstructs the 1986 nuclear disaster from the perspectives of people present during its devastation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Citadel says it will move offices to Miami because of crime in Chicago.
description: The hedge fund made the announcement after simmering tensions between its founder and the Illinois governor.
content: The hedge fund Citadel and the trading firm Citadel Securities, both run by the billionaire Ken Griffin, are moving their offices to Miami after more than three decades in Chicago, according to a memo to employees that was obtained by The New York Times on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: The Stranded Sons of Shakhtar Donetsk
description: One of Ukraine’s top soccer teams rushed its youth academy players out of the path of war in February. Months later, many of the boys are stuck in a lonely limbo.
content: SPLIT, Croatia — It was in their moment of triumph, when they had beaten their opponents and come together to collect their medals, when some of the boys were overcome with sadness, when the tears welled in their eyes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Their Baby Died. Then a Boston Hospital Lost the Body.
description: Everleigh McCarthy was less than 2 weeks old when she died at Brigham and Women’s Hospital in 2020. The police said her remains were “probably mistaken as soiled linen” and discarded.
content: Everleigh Victoria McCarthy was born three months premature at Brigham and Women’s Hospital in Boston and weighed a little over two pounds. Soon after her birth on July 25, 2020, she developed massive bleeding in her brain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Strikes Down New York Law Limiting Guns in Public
description: The decision, based on a broad interpretation of the Second Amendment, will make it harder for states and localities to restrict guns outside the home.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Thursday that Americans have a broad right to arm themselves in public, striking down a New York law that placed strict limits on carrying guns outside the home and setting off a scramble in other states that have similar restrictions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheera Frenkel and Cecilia Kang
title: As Midterms Loom, Elections Are No Longer Top Priority for Meta C.E.O.
description: Mark Zuckerberg, who once said securing elections was “the most important thing,” has shifted Meta’s focus to the metaverse. That may have real-world implications.
content: Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, made securing the 2020 U.S. election a top priority. He met regularly with an election team, which included more than 300 people from across his company, to prevent misinformation from spreading on the social network. He asked civil rights leaders for advice on upholding voter rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: A Monkeypox Vaccine Is Now Available for New Yorkers Who May Be at Risk
description: Demand for the vaccine was high as the city began offering the vaccine at one Chelsea clinic, where a long line formed and people were turned away.
content: Facing a growing outbreak of the monkeypox virus, New York City health officials expanded access to a monkeypox vaccine on Thursday, offering it to a new group of people who may be at higher risk: men who have had multiple or anonymous male sexual partners over the last two weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Harry Gesner, Architect of Soaring California Style, Dies at 97
description: His houses cantilevered from cliffs, straddled canyons and sprung from mountains; they would come to define the Southern California landscape.
content: Harry Gesner, the dashing, surf-loving architect whose soaring designs celebrated California’s dramatic landscape in houses that straddled canyons, perched over beaches and cantilevered from cliffs, died on June 10 at his home in Malibu, Calif., a whorl of a place called the Sandcastle. He was 97.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Lessons in Survival: 1971’ Review: The Past Echoes in the Present
description: The writer James Baldwin and the poet Nikki Giovanni are at the center of a crackling work of verbatim theater at the Vineyard Theater.
content: If the year weren’t in the title, you might come close to guessing it from the architecture of the sunken space: a conversation pit lined with couches upholstered in burnt orange, with blood orange carpeting to match. There’s a comfort to the room, a midcentury modern hospitality that invites you to take your shoes off, have a drink, light one cigarette after another, and talk and talk as you try to set the world to rights.
source.name: The New York Times

content: Alex Holder, a British documentary filmmaker who had extensive access to President Donald J. Trump and his family ahead of and after the 2020 election, has emerged late in the House’s investigation of the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol as a new and potentially important witness.

title: The U.S. announces an additional $450 million in military aid for Ukraine.

author: By Jack Tamisiea
title: Centenarian Tortoises May Set the Standard for Anti-Aging
description: Tortoises and turtles don’t just live for a long time — they barely age while they live.
content: For mammals like humans, aging is inevitable. No matter how many vitamins we take, skin sags, bones soften and joints stiffen over time. However, turtles and tortoises age more gracefully. Despite their wrinkled skin and toothless gums, species like Galápagos giant tortoises seem unscathed by the ravages of aging. Some show few signs of slowing down as they plod into their 100s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan
title: Overburdened Penn Station Needs More Tracks. But Where Could They Fit?
description: As debate rages on a plan to renovate the nation’s busiest hub, Amtrak awarded a contract to design a $12 billion expansion that would add train capacity.
content: Nearly everyone agrees that something must be done to fix the chaos at Pennsylvania Station in New York City, the nation’s busiest transit hub. Now comes the hard part of devising a solution that will steer clear of controversy.

description: In the aftermath of the Supreme Court ruling, Gov. Kathy Hochul will call a special legislative session to look for ways to maintain New York’s restrictive gun laws.

title: Florida Biologists Capture 215-Pound Burmese Python
description: The Conservancy of Southwest Florida, which tracks and studies invasive Burmese pythons harming the state’s native ecosystem, said the nearly 18-foot female python was the largest to have been found in the Everglades.
